detail.content: Abjection: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Performance Studies About the Program Admissions BA Program MA Program PhD Program Course Offerings Admin & Faculty Students Alumni PS Spotlights  News & Events Projects & Publications Blog Facebook  home > Performance Studies        Abjection  H42.2622 Lec 4 Credits Instructor(s): Karen Shimakawa H42.2622-001 (Albert #76770) Wednesday 12:30 pm – 3:15 pm, 4 points 721 Broadway, Room 613    Disgust, revulsion, abhorrence -- how do they arise, and why? What is the social function of extreme repulsion, and how is it performative? In this course, we will examine several theories of such feelings, and consider how they produce social relations, structures and identities. How and why are particular objects, substances, actions, identities rendered repellent, and what are the political and aesthetic projects that are either enabled or disabled in that process? Readings will be drawn from a range of theoretical approaches (psychoanalytic, anthropological, legal, medical) and students will be encouraged to consider their applicability (or inapplicability) to your own research fields. Requirements: weekly reading responses, student presentations, and a final research paper/project.
